„ÄêJingluo Eighth Society ¬∑ Baifeng Shrine„Äë

Baifeng Shrine, formerly known as Baifeng Palace, was built in the first year of Meiji (1868 AD) to worship Emperor Sutoku and Emperor Junren who died in the place where they died. The shrine of Shiramine Jingu Shrine is the main family of Cuju, the residence site of the Asuka family, and the landowner Shajing Daimyojin is the patron saint of Cuju, and is now regarded as the patron saint of various ball skills and sports such as football.

Beside the main hall are balls donated by many professional sports players, including balls used by the Japanese national team at the World Cup and Olympic Games. There are many signatures of professional sports players in the shrine. In addition, there are many footballs, baseballs, basketballs, volleyballs, badmintons, rugby balls, etc. next to the shrine. They are all used by professional sports players. You can take pictures and touch them to pray for victory. transport.

Author: Hiroshi Kyoto
Review:
It is a former Kanpei Taisha shrine that was built by Emperor Meiji in 1868 (the beginning of the Meiji era), transferring the spirit of Emperor Sutoku from Shiramine Mausoleum in Sanuki. Later, in 1873, Emperor Junnin transferred his spirit from the Awaji mausoleum and was enshrined together. Emperor Sutoku, the enshrined deity, was exiled in the "Hogen Rebellion," and Emperor Junnin was exiled in the "Fujiwara no Nakamaro Rebellion."
The Jinshu Shrine on the grounds of the shrine is famous as the God of Kemari and Stars. Founded: 1868 (Meiji 1).
It is an old shrine that was built by Emperor Meiji in 1868 (the original Meiji era) by transferring the spirit of Emperor Sutoku from the Shiramine Mausoleum in Sanuki. Later, in the 6th year of the Meiji era, Emperor Junnin also transferred the spirit from the Awaji Mausoleum and was enshrined. Emperor Sutoku, the deity of the ritual, was exiled to the "Hogen Rebellion" and Emperor Junnin was exiled to the "Fujiwara no Nakamaro Ran".
The precincts landowner "Seidai Myojin" is famous as the god of Cuju and the stars. Founded: 1868 (1868).

Author: Á¥∫Á¢ßËñÑÁ¥Ö
Review:
It is a shrine with an elegant atmosphere that makes you feel as if a nobleman appears. When I heard about the vengeful spirit of Emperor Sutoku on TV, I thought it was a scary place. What is the height of expansion?

However, even after hundreds of years, it seems that the strong feelings that made him called the vengeful spirit of Emperor Sutoku remained. Emperor Sutoku is counted as one of Japan's three greatest vengeful spirits, but unlike the other two who were philosophical, it seemed that he still had the feeling of wanting to clear his regrets and not giving up. His dignity was exceptionally the best, and he was so dignified that he was called the emperor.

The amulets of Shiramine Jingu also contain the strong power of Emperor Sutoku, so it gives the impression that ordinary evil spirits will be astonished and flee. I was worried about the red bill and the yellow bill. My impression is that a red amulet should be used to cut off a strong bad relationship that cannot be helped, and a yellow amulet should be used for a weak bad relationship that is likely to turn into a good one.

The bills you receive also have weight. Since it is a bill, it is as thin as a piece of paper, but the weight of the air around it is amazing. The presence of the talisman is amazing. Never forget that you have a bill. Once you put the talisman on, the stagnant air with poor airflow that worries you about renting is gone.

It's a big bell at the time of worship, but this is also amazing. I had an image that my wish would come true when I rang it. It is a mysterious bell, so it is recommended to ring it when visiting the shrine.

Author: Massa S.
Review: Shiramine Jingu / Shiramina Jinguu Shrine A shrine that enshrines Emperor Sutoku and Emperor Junnin, who were exiled and died there. The site of Shiramine Jingu Shrine is the former site of the mansion of the Asukai family, the head family of kemari. Seidaimyojin, enshrined in the landlord shrine, is the guardian deity of kemari, and is now considered to be the guardian deity of not only soccer but also ball games in general and sports.

Author: „Åæ„Çä„Çä„Çì
Review:
From Nijo Castle, head north on Horikawa Street, cross Seimei Shrine on your left, turn right at the intersection of Horikawa Imadegawa, and you will find Shiramine Jingu on your left. The enshrined deities are the 75th Emperor Sutoku and the 47th Emperor Junnin. Speaking of Emperor Sutoku (Sutokuin), the disaster caused by his power was so powerful that he was counted as one of Japan's three great vengeful spirits (Sugawara no Michizane, Taira no Masakado, and Sutokuin).
On August 18th, 4th year of Keio, Emperor Meiji sent an imperial messenger to Sanuki to conduct the ceremony of his enthronement, so that the spirit of Emperor Sutoku could return to Kyoto and Shiramine Jingu Shrine was built here. The reason why Emperor Junnin is enshrined is because he was also exiled 400 years ago from Sutoku-in Temple.
Around here, near Horikawa Imadegawa, Seimei Shrine, Ichijo Modoribashi, and other unique places in Kyoto, I am very attracted.
I feel that there is an indescribable atmosphere in this modern age.
Another reason why Shiramine Jingu Shrine is famous is that the Seidai Daimyojin Shrine, a subsidiary shrine, protects the improvement of sports and arts, so many people, such as the Japanese soccer team, visit the shrine. and we can see it.
If you are interested, please visit us. The monument of Ogura Hyakunin Isshu, in which Sutokuin was written, will bring tears to your eyes.

Originally, the guardian deity started from Kemari in Japan. It is said that this fallinai is good for taking exams, and it seems to have spread as a good omen.

When you enter the precincts, there are "Sakon's cherry blossoms and Ukon's tachibana trees". Here, he explains his surprise when he was named Nadeshiko Japan in soccer. In addition, the tachibana tree welcomed us with fine fruit.

Visit the "Nademari Monument" and Ema (votive tablet) wishing for victory, Jishu Shrine, Bano Shrine, Senryu Shrine, and finally "Ball Bell". Certainly, I remember that Sota Shrine at Shimogamo Shrine was the god of rugby.

Senryu-sha Shrine is located in the farthest, inconspicuous place, and the water from the well next to it is said to sever bad connections.

There is a monument that Sutoku-in wrote, ``Even if Takigawa rushes to the river, I think that I will meet at the end.''

Minamoto no Tametomo, enshrined in Banosha, is said to be the first Ryukyu king. In addition, because he was called Chinzei Hachiro, his nephew Minamoto no Yoshitsune dared to call him Kuro instead of Hachiro, even though he was a man, and I feel his respect for Tametomo.

In the old days, no tourists came to the small shrine in the neighborhood. There was a Shinto priest who helped clean up and gave me candy.

Gingko nuts fall from mid-November.

The divine spirits of Emperor Sutoku, who was exiled to Sanuki during the Hogen War, and Emperor Junnin, who was exiled to Awaji due to Dokyo's plot, are to be returned to this area as gods for the protection of the imperial family and the fulfillment of one's wishes. Author: Èä≠Á•ê
Review:
This shrine is located along Imadegawa Street. Shrines that enshrine the ancestral deities of the imperial family, successive emperors, and gods that are closely related to the imperial family are called Jingu. It is said that the deity enshrined here is the deity of the ball called Seidaimyojin. The Asukai family, who have enshrined and worshiped it, are regarded as the sacred grounds and guardian deities of kemari (soccer) as the head family of kemari, and are worshiped as the god of all ball games. Therefore, there are various balls such as soccer balls, volleyballs, and baseballs in the precincts, and there are also colored papers of athletes associated with them. Review:
On April 25, 2010, I visited "Kyoto Undisclosed Cultural Property Special Exhibition".

This area used to be the residence of the Asukai family, the masters of Kemari and Waka poetry.
In 1868, Emperor Meiji moved the spirit of Emperor Sutoku to this place and built it.
Later, the spirit of Emperor Junnin was also enshrined.
Both Emperor Sutoku and Emperor Junnin were driven out of the capital and died in exile.
They were enshrined at Shiramine Jingu Shrine to comfort their spirits and obtain divine protection.

The subordinate shrine and landlord shrine enshrine Seidaimyojin, the god of Kemari. In recent years, it has been worshiped as the god of sports improvement.
In addition, since kemari does not drop the ball, it is believed to be the god of passing exams and improving academic ability.

This time, I was able to see the costume of Kemari, the ball, the statue of Emperor Sutoku (reproduction), and the biwa.

Author: Ê≤ôÊµ∑ÊΩõË°å / Desertstalker
Review:
Spring morning light, benefit wind and smooth

Cu is kicking, Ju is ball. Cuju means to play football.
It was first introduced from China as the training of samurai.
It later became an athletics game in Japan, a nobleman's game, and a ritual today.

On April 14 every year, it is a spring ceremony in honor of Emperor Junnin
Held at the Asuka family, which has been the main family of cuju since ancient times, at today's Shiramine Shrine.

Early in the morning, many people were already waiting in front of the open space next to the shrine, and some of them watched the ceremony in front of the shrine.
After the priestess performed the ceremony with a dagger dance, the priests awarded honors to the gentlemen in formal attire, and finally took out the sacrificial items from the high room.
Then, Cuju officially began.

After the referee placed the ball in the center of the open space, the players squatted around the ball one by one, and after paying homage to the emperor, they began to kick the ball.

Shiramine Shrine is the place of protection of the football god.
Therefore, players of all-Japan ball games,
Many will enshrine the ball at Shiramine Shrine.

Author: Maboo Nakano
Review:
The Asukai family, whose family business is waka poetry and kemari, moved to Tokyo with the emperor during the Meiji Restoration, and Emperor Meiji enshrined Emperor Sutoku and Emperor Junnin together to create Shiramine Palace on the site of the Asukai family's mansion. In 1940, it was renamed Shiramine Jingu.
What remains is the Oga Tamaki tree, the Mari no Sei Daimyojin enshrined at the landlord's shrine, and the name of the town of Asukai. Today, kemari, in which balls are passed without dropping, has become a status, and many people visit the shrine to pray for improvement and victory in all ball sports.

Author: S F
Review: It is said that Emperor Meiji welcomed the spirit of Emperor Sutoku to Shiramine Mausoleum in Kagawa Prefecture in the first year of the Meiji era. It is said that the shrine was later enshrined with the divine spirit of Emperor Junnin from Awaji Island. Originally, this area was the residence of the Asukai family, the head family of kemari, so it is said to be revered by athletes such as soccer and ball games. It is located northwest of the Imperial Palace, right in front of the Horikawa-Imadegawa bus stop, making it easy to access. I was prepared because it was a shrine that enshrines Emperor Sutoku, one of Japan's three great vengeful spirits, but it was a very pleasant shrine. I would like to visit again.
